comment: this implies that morality cannot arise from reason--plugging for Kant perhaps?

{{Redirect|Appropriate||Appropriation (disambiguation)}}
 
{{Redirect|Appropriate||Appropriation (disambiguation)}}
−
'''Morality''' (from the [[Latin]] ''{{Lang|la|moralitas}}'' "manner, character, proper behavior") is an [[intuition (knowledge)|intuitive]] or [[social construct|socially developed]] [[understanding]] that differentiates intentions, decisions, and [[Social actions|actions]] between those that are good (or right) and bad (or wrong). A ''moral code'' is a system of morality (for example, according to a particular [[philosophy]], [[religion]], [[culture]], etc.) and a ''moral'' is any one practice or teaching within a moral code. The [[adjective]] ''moral'' is synonymous with "good" or "right." ''Immorality'' is the active opposition to what one believes to be moral (i.e. good or right), while ''amorality'' is variously defined as an unawareness of, indifference toward, or lack of belief in any set of moral standards or principles.
+
'''Morality''' (from the [[Latin]] ''{{Lang|la|moralitas}}'' "manner, character, proper behavior") is the [[understanding]] that differentiates among intentions, decisions, and [[Social actions|actions]] between those that are good (or right) and bad (or wrong). A ''moral code'' is a system of morality (for example, according to a particular [[philosophy]], [[religion]], [[culture]], etc.) and a ''moral'' is any one practice or teaching within a moral code. The [[adjective]] ''moral'' is synonymous with "good" or "right." ''Immorality'' is the active opposition to what one believes to be moral (i.e. good or right), while ''amorality'' is variously defined as an unawareness of, indifference toward, or disbelief in any set of moral standards or principles.
